Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2013 01:36AM SPAMgirl wrote: I think you have to be on SSDI for 18 months before you qualify for Medicare. I'm going to brag about my company, Hormel, for the most part. The CEO of the company wrote a policy letter stating that anyone with a terminal disease has the right to work as long as they can complete their duties. We have 54 weeks of short-term disability with 90% pay. I was able to retire with a pension at 39 since I had worked there for over 15 years. My DH will receive 75% of my pension once I'm deceased. The HR department did/is doing absolutely everything they can to take care of me. The most amazing part is that they re-hired my DH. He had been looking for a job to no avail. The director of his department wanted to make sure my kids were okay so they hired him. He has worked for Hormel before and had all of the qualifications needed for the job. Hormel has been fantastic, but my immediate boss did push me out the door. He knows that I'm a believer in following all of the rules and he directed me to stop being...less of an employee than I was. He knew that would push me out the door. I think he was tired of hearing about how I was going to die. He even went so far as to tell me that I should just drink more water instead of getting fluids. I had even repeatedly told him how much I needed to work for my mental well-being. He has always come across as being nice, but he's really slimey behind closed doors. Since Hormel has been so awesome to me, eat SPAM!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 10:35PM SPAMgirl wrote: I was in terrible pain, opioids made me nauseous, constipated and loopy. My doctor recommended a neurosurgeon to install a pain pump. I have a metal pump in my abdomen and a catheter that feeds directly into my spine like an epidural. I have a boost button that I can push if I need a little exta. Since it goes directly into my spine, the pain medicine doesn't affect any other part of my body. I go to the neurosurgeon's office every 4 months to get my pump refilled. It is very easy for the nurse to increase or decrease the dosage amount. I never think about taking pain medicine unless I need some breakthrough help. I am so glad I have it.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2013 06:40PM SPAMgirl wrote: The first time around, the radiation was directly aimed at the skin and chest wall and your skin becomes burnt. When the rads were aiming for my pelvis bone, they were aimed deeper than my skin. It the rads are aimed closer to the skin, I found an amazing 'cooling pad' from LINDI SKIN. It literally takes your skin temperature down 10 degrees and has aloe, etc. I used this for my 35 rads after my mastectomy and I didn't get a blister.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2012 09:41PM SPAMgirl wrote: I LOVE my pain pump. The doc. can adjust it for more of less medicine. Since the medicine (morphine in my case) goes into my spine and doesn't have to go through my entire body, it doesn't take as much to control the pain. That means I'm a lot less loopy and I can drive without hesitation. The patches were nice, but I got really loopy. I had a 7cm tumor in my pelvis. They promised me that radiation would help, but the tumor outgrew the area being radiated. Then I became so constipated from the all of the opiates, that I ended up in the hospital for 2 days to get cleared out. Did I mention that I love my worry-free pain pump. I'm currently going in every couple months to dial in the dosage, but soon I'll be able to space them out to 3-6 months. They did give my a "push" button so I can get an exta hit every 4 hours as needed. Right now, I think about pain medicine less than once per week. Good luck with whatever you choose. It's bad enough to be IV, we shouldn't have pain with it!

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2012 06:29PM SPAMgirl wrote: I was at my X-mas party last night and one of the wives mentioned that it was really hot in the room. I agreed as sweat was rolling down my neck. She told me she was hot because she was going through menopause. I told her that my cancer loves the hormones, so they put me in menopause too. Then she asked what estrogen drug I was using to help with the hot flashes. I repeated that i can't have lthe hormones because of the cancer. This is a smart woman. I just told her that I can have estrogen. Then she asked me if I was estring. I don't even know what the hell that was, but I was starting to get really jealous that she could take something for her menopause symptoms. I don't think she knew I was IV, so I wasn't upset when she asked me how many more treatments I had left. I said the rest of my life and she still looked confused. This is were I hate telling people that this is terminal and it's not like I'll be doing chemo for that long. I hate having that feeling like I need to lie and protect people from mortality. I felt like I slapped her in the face.

Make sure you ask a lot of questions about the color and shape of the lump and what it means.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 04:45AM SPAMgirl wrote: After so much pain, my doc inserted a pain pump. It releases a small dose of morphine 24 hours/day. Since the morphine is delivered directly into my spine like an epidural, it doesn't have the effects on my body that viciden does. I needed oxy to control the pain before my pump and now my morphine dose is so little, the rest of my body isn't affected. I can think clearly and my bowels are working correctly. They gave me a little booster button that lasts for 4 hours on bad days, but I'm sure they could program that for 8 hours to get you through the night without pain. Hope you guys find something that works. Beth

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 11:30AM SPAMgirl wrote: I ended up in the hospital from the constipation from the pain medicine, which is why they switched me to a pain pump. I had done everything to relieve the constipation and nothing, not even enemas worked. I had waited too long before I started to become serious about fixing it. They gave me the drink they give people before a colonoscopy. Afterwards, they gave me Regulan and I had shots of something that I had to give myself every other day. Hopefully you can clear up before all of that happens. I take senokot or colace on a regular basis, a couple of times per week. I also put a capful of Mirilax in my coffee every morning. Try to stay away from bananas and cheese. I was told to switch between fleet enemas and warm water ones. The other thing I did was switch to a chemo that provides a lot of diarrhea. It's been a nice balance with my constipation. This is the only part of your condition I know anything about. I really don't have any words for the things you are going through, so I'm going to end you lots of ((((((HUGS))))))

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 01:50PM SPAMgirl wrote: 1) What story does your family always tell about you?  The more embarrassing the better! When I was a toddler, I would strip naked every time my clothes got wet.  They always wondered how long it would take my dates to figure it out. 2) What is your favorite indoor and outdoor activity? I spend much of my outdoor time watching my kids play soccer.  If I'm inside, I like to dabble on my iPad. 3) What is the main thing that makes you unique? I have a strong personality that likes to plan.  Typically, I'll plan out a trip the most efficient way possible so that everybody can get what they want at the lowest cost and in the least amount of time.  Some of my friends call it scheming, I call it planning:) 4) What is your favorite memory - as a child and as an adult? I loved taking trips to see my Grandmother ad a child.  She lived 2 days away so I only got to see her every other year. As an adult, a groups of friends and I went to San Fransico and had the craziest time ever.  We had a guy walk off the sidewalk and spit on our windshield, took a taxi to dinner and the driver kept trying to convince me I should go the S&M festival and on the flight home, they pulled our airplane away from the building because of a potential bomb (this was pre 9-11.)  They didn't let us get off the plane, just moved the plane away from the terminal.  That was just a few highlights of the many crazy things that happened.  I certainly wasn't in Kansas anymore. 5) You have said that you love your job.  What do you do and what is the best part? I'm an Industrial Engineer and I love trying to lower the costs of our products while trying to make the jobs easier for our employees.  That probably goes with my love for planning.  Bonus question: If you have 30 minutes have unexpected free time (and you are feeling well) what do you do with the time? With any free time I have, I'm reading BCO.  i think it drives my Husband crazy because he is trying to forget that I'm going to die. Bonus bonus question: Why SPAMgirl? I work for Hormel Foods, the company that makes SPAM!  It pays my salary, so I'm very thankful.  In case anybody was wondering, SPAM is make out of ham meat and the meat from pork chops.  While it has very good, quaily, lean meat in it, it does contain a lot of salt and starch.   Hormel has been an exceptional company to work for during this mess.  The CEO even has made a clear policy that if a terminal employee is able to show up to work and do something productive, they will keep their job. One of our Vice-Presidents called my plant after he retired just to see how I was doing.  My husband was having a hard time finding a job since he had taken time off to take care of me.  They asked him to interview with them and gave him a job.  (He had worked for them before, that's how we met.)  They truely care about their employees.

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 06:01PM SPAMgirl wrote: They told me they would look for the mutation in my DNA chain. If they found it in mine, they would know exactly where in the chain to look for my relatives. The cost for the original test was $4000. If I was positive, they could run the test on my children for $500 since they wouldn't have to look at the entire chain, just the part where my mutation was found. I do have friends that have had breast removal and reconstruction before they were 30 because they tested positive after their Mother had been diagnosed. I know there is room for error, but I feel better for my doctor. My insurance paid for it, so it was an easy decision. I hope that she can use that information when she applies for life insurance, etc when she gets older. I know they love to ask questions of your parents health records and telling them that your Mom died of BC would certainly increase her rates.
Posts.Title: Is bc genetic testing really necessary? Kaelia Kaelia

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 08:47PM SPAMgirl wrote: Every health form they fill out, they have to list their parent's medical history. (My Dad has diabetes, my grandfather had heart problems, etc.). From now on, my children will have to report that their mother has/had BC on all of those forms. My children do not have the disease and it is not a pre-existing condition, but they will be watched for BC just like my Dad has been watched for heart disease. Under Obamacare, pre-existing conditions can not stop someone from getting healthcare. A life insurance company would look at that health care question and assess the chance that my daughter would get BC genetically from me. It probably wouldn't matter, but she could contest the higher rate because she has proof it's not genetic. If it was positive, my daughter would be watched more closely by her medical doctors.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 09:13PM SPAMgirl wrote: When they shut down my hormones and put me into chemo pause, I had terrible hot flashes and night sweats. I found that 300 mg of Effexor ( venlafaxine) really stopped those side effects. If you have bone pain from a bone met, they can radiate to lessen the pain. You need to make sure the mets are someplace where the bone is not likely to break like the top of your femur. If they are, your doc, might send you to an orthopedic surgeon to strengthen that bone with metal plate. Lots of things can happen and you have every right in the world to freak. I think most of us have had a nice solid three-four months of freaking plus exta pity parties thrown in. Take care, make sure you get copies of all your lab results and ask your doctors lots of questions.

We want them to know they are loved and safe among all else.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 12:24AM SPAMgirl wrote: The trend of the TM is more important than the actual numbers. If you're trending up over a period of time, it could mean progression. TM do not work for everybody, a scan will tell the reliable story. My TM have followed the trend of my scans, so I trust them to tell me a fairly accurate story. Also be aware that if the TMs work for you, you will generally see a huge spike after you start a new chemo. It's called a tumor flare because your body has not had time to flush out the dead cells. If you have regression, the TM should start to trend downward after the flare is over. Again, TM aren't reliable for everyone. Scans will tell the true story. The trend is more important than the number and you will see a spike after you start a new chemo. Good luck.

Posts.Content: SPAMgirl wrote: This decease sucks monkey balls. Why do we fight it so hard? We spend the majority of our time miserable. We are in pain, anxiously waiting for scans. Dealing with horrible SEs and just waiting for the next trip to the hospital. Waiting for the next mets to show up. The next nurse/hospital staff to make the next error. Did I mention the horrible SEs. (mouth sores, nasuea, numb fingers and toes, cracked feet, fluid around our stomaches or lungs, shortness of breath, excess fatigue, bone pain, low white cells where weep cant hug our sick children, etc.) I can't always walk in a straight line. I bounce off the walls walking up the stairs. My fingers are numb and I have very, very minor SEs. Depending on our healthcare coverage, we are putting our family in debt. I want to take another family vacation, but my husband refuses to put us in debt even he knows there is enough life insurance to cover the vacation when I'm gone. Our kids and husbands and other family are just sitting on the edge of a rail waiting for us to tip over into death. Husbands start to distance themselves so they aren't as emotionally hurt by our death. We have had so many surgeries that we have been mutalated to into Frankenstien and are no longer attractive. Or we've gained 50 pounds from treatment or lost 30 and look stick thin and unhealthy. Again, unattractive to our spouses because we don't look like we did in our twenties. You can throw intimacy out the window. I guess I don't really need extra hugs from my husband right now. There is little to no intimacy in the sex department because we aren't physically attractive anymore. So much for trying to attacf the When is it better to just let my family start over their new life without me. Waiting in limbo sucks. I thought it would suck for 6 months to a year. Depending on how long this chemo works, I could make their lives miserable for much longer than that !!!!! All of our kids do is worry about our impending death. When does it become more of a present to just let them all move on with their lives. My husband lost his job just before my original diagnosis and had been with been throughout everything. Now he has a four-year gap on his resume which I know majorly hurts his chances of finding a new job. Again, my fault for having cancer. Think of all the hardship you have given on you and your family by going through treatment. Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 06:34AM SPAMgirl wrote: Blood counts would be very important to check. If you get the chance, I would recommend the check your ammonia too. It doesn't sound like your liver has been destroyed, but my liver stopped filtering out all of the waste it was supposed to. I ended up with ammonia in my brain and I was incapable of doing anything. They checked my ammonia counts with my blood work and it showed high. There is medicine they can give if that is the case. They game me Lactulose (made me vomit.) After that fails, they can give you a medicine called Xifaxan. My onc had never heard of Xifaxan and it's been wonderful. It was prescribed by my GI doctor.

I bounce off the walls walking up the stairs. My fingers are numb and I have very, very minor SEs. Depending on our healthcare coverage, we are putting our family in debt. I want to take another family vacation, but my husband refuses to put us in debt even he knows there is enough life insurance to cover the vacation when I'm gone. Our kids and husbands and other family are just sitting on the edge of a rail waiting for us to tip over into death. Husbands start to distance themselves so they aren't as emotionally hurt by our death. We have had so many surgeries that we have been mutalated to into Frankenstien and are no longer attractive. Or we've gained 50 pounds from treatment or lost 30 and look stick thin and unhealthy. Again, unattractive to our spouses because we don't look like we did in our twenties. You can throw intimacy out the window. I guess I don't really need extra hugs from my husband right now. There is little to no intimacy in the sex department because we aren't physically attractive anymore. So much for trying to attacf the When is it better to just let my family start over their new life without me. Waiting in limbo sucks. I thought it would suck for 6 months to a year. Depending on how long this chemo works, I could make their lives miserable for much longer than that !!!!! All of our kids do is worry about our impending death. When does it become more of a present to just let them all move on with their lives. My husband lost his job just before my original diagnosis and had been with been throughout everything. Now he has a four-year gap on his resume which I know majorly hurts his chances of finding a new job. Again, my fault for having cancer. Think of all the hardship you have given on you and your family by going through treatment. Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2013 10:05AM SPAMgirl wrote: I went through a similar situation. After my first 2 cycles of chemo after getting liver mets, I had terrible progression. I had about 2 weeks to live when they switched my chemo. Within the first week of the new chemo, I had tremendous regression. I had regression every cycle for 9 months before I had a tiny progression and switched chemos. There is tremendous hope that your next chemo will be a magic bullet and blow those little bastards to the sky. I found a book at Barnes & Noble called, "All About Me." It's a journal with set questions for you to answer. Where did you grow up, who was your best friend, what did you guys do together, what was your first job, etc. Once I could get past the tears everytime I opened the book, I started to fill it out. I like that the kids will have a chance to read about my life even after I'm gone. I also got a book about my relationship with their father where it asked questions about where we met, what we did on our first date. How did we decide to get married, etc. since I've been feeling better, I've been bad on filling out those books.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2012 12:30AM SPAMgirl wrote: I have bone mets in different parts of my body. My main one is on the inside of my pelvis. The tumor outgrew the radiation, so it didn't stop the pain. I was in horrible pain, and I was sent to a neurosurgeon. He installed an interrathecal pain pump. It is filled with morphine and dripped directly into my spinal column like an epidural. Since it goes directly into my spine, I don't need as strong of a dose as the narcotics. Depending on my pain, they can increase the amount of morphine drip whenever I need it. I also have a push button to give me an extra dose for four hours. Prior to the pump, I was immobilized and severally constipated. Now, pain killers rarely cross my mind, my bowels are in good shape, and I'm not loopy from the narcotics. My only downside is the scar. He certainly was not a plastic surgeon!!! Good luck with whatever you decide.
